{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3171979,"name":"Brian Wagg","username":"cad321","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/c/c57346/{size}.png","created_at":"2023-03-24T03:27:12.512Z","cooked":"

Hi all, forgive me but here’s another thread from a team asking for some guidance with swerve code .

This year 3739 made the jump to swerve, and have been absolutely thrilled with our experience with it (specifically running REV MAXSwerve modules). We’re at a point where we have a “basic” auto where we score mid cube and balance on the charge station. The team is now hoping to try and further our abilities during auto, and are hitting some roadblocks as we try to implement trajectory following.

A quick disclaimer, I am not a programming person by any stretch of the imagination, but have taught myself some basics over the years to try and help my teams out where I can. Any guidance provided here I’ll be passing along to our programming team and helping them walk through it.

The issue; We’re using the example MAXSwerve code and can follow the example “S” curve trajectory fairly well. We can also drive forwards and backwards in a straight line with consistent results. However, when we try to add in any rotation to our trajectory waypoints, we get some rather odd (well, odd to us) behavior. See these videos for examples:

Our code is public and can be found here:

github.com

GitHub - Oakbotics/2023-FRC-Code at Distance-Auto

Distance-Auto

Contribute to Oakbotics/2023-FRC-Code development by creating an account on GitHub.

Currently we are trying to use our “GoDistanceSwerveCommand” to go from the robots current/initial pose, to a user defined destination pose (the video of the robot trying to drive 2 meters forward while turning 90°).

For the S curve auto, we are running our “SwerveExampleAuto” command.

Both seem to work fine until we tell the robot to change it’s rotation (rotation2d) while executing the trajectory. Our 2 leading theories are that we’re having issues with the robot being in (or not being in) field oriented mode while following the trajectories, or that our PID values need to be seriously tuned.

If option 2 is the issue (PID tuning needed), we’re hopelessly lost and would love some starting suggestions on how to tune these values. In our last commit tonight, our P value for our X and Y controller are now different (we were trying to see what would happen when making them different), but for all our testing/videos, the P values for the X and Y controller was 5.

Apologies for the lengthy post, but we could really use some advice . If there is any clarification needed, please don’t hesitate to say so!

programming mentor FRC 2930","username":"randomstring","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/randomstring/{size}/170695_2.png","created_at":"2023-03-24T16:48:04.568Z","cooked":"

Have you tried testing a path driving straight forward and turning? Start with driving forward 2m and turn 180 degrees. Use that to tune your rotation kP.

And if you still struggling, go simpler still. Drive straight forward 1, 2, 3 meters and make sure those are accurate. This will improve your chances that you have your feedforward constants correct. Then add in a single curve: drive forward 1 meter and to the left 1 meter in an arc. Once you’re happy with those, then add in rotation.

0.1 seems small for a rotational kP, but our team uses SDS mk4 w/ falcons, a completely different setup. Maybe someone else with MAXSwerve can sanity check this.

Appreciate the reply!

So far we have the robot accurately following a path where we go 2 and 4 meters forward (or backwards) in a nice straight line. The second we add any form of rotation to it (we’ve been trying to turn 90° mostly, but same effect the odd time we’ve tried 180°), it struggles hard.

With regards to our rotation kP, if we bump it any higher than 0.13, the robot heavily oscillates and starts working itself backwards when we’re commanding it forwards. I wish we’d managed to get a video of it doing that too. My initial thought was that the code wasn’t allowing the robot to turn fast enough during the trajectory, causing it to behave the way it is in the videos; But any time we increase P to try that, we start to see that heavy oscillation I mention.

I have not looked at your code and am just guessing: you should check if your Auto driving is field centric or robot centric. You might be getting those results because you think you are driving field-centric but are really doing robot-centric.

One thing to try: try driving in a staight line, but not forward, do it sideways. So, can you drive correctly straight left (w.r.t. your robot’s “forward”)?
